ranked_diseases.explanation: All three reference cases with similar phenotypes (amyloidosis of peripheral nerves and chronic diarrhea) were diagnosed with this condition. The patient's presentation closely matches these cases.
TTR-related hereditary amyloidosis commonly presents with peripheral nerve involvement and gastrointestinal symptoms including diarrhea and constipation. Age of onset fits with late-onset variant.
Another form of hereditary amyloidosis that can present with peripheral neuropathy and autonomic dysfunction affecting the GI tract, though less specific match to reference cases.
Apolipoprotein A1-related amyloidosis can involve peripheral nerves and cause GI symptoms, though typically has more prominent renal or hepatic involvement.
AL amyloidosis can present with peripheral neuropathy and GI involvement, though the hereditary forms seem more likely given the reference cases and specific phenotype combination.
